text: going to be a margin requirement and the margin requirement is going to depend on if you have margin account what margin positions you uh permissions you have in this case I'm using a pass through Ira so what that means is there's nothing in the account but more importantly than that you'll notice that the margin requirement for this 55 put is 5,500 because in the IRA account you can't have naked puts it has to be cash secured if you have a margin account then maybe you have regulation t or if you have a slightly bigger account you can have portfolio margin the one thing to note about this specifically the margin requirement for selling premium is that it changes as the broker perceives more risk they are going to expand the margin requirement they're not going to take the risk for you so they're going to give you the leverage meaning you can control X size position putting up a smaller amount of money whatever that margin is but they're going to adjust it based on their risk and they're going to pass that on to you that doesn't happen when you buy options buying options is whatever it is right from the jump and a quick note just on the Greeks for those that are curious when you buy premium you're short Theta this simply means as time passes your options lose value in the form of feta Decay when you buy premium you're long

text: both of these this is why my overall approach to trading which I'll throw a link to that below as well I actively use both and it's because they each have a use case for me so now what's the next primary tip here it's don't default one of the things that I find people will do is they will automatically think oh I'm going to sell premium here I'm going to buy premium and what I think about instead is fitting The Profit mechanism and your risk preference and this is part of something I call the outlier strategy process I have a video as well that I'll link to Below on this but the thing I really want to focus on here is this idea of outlining fitting structures this is step three so let's take a quick look at an example together if we pop over into here and we take a look at Palance here if for whatever reason we had that position we talked about that perspective trade that came in on the 5th and we think that paler is going to have a big move if we think that there's going to be a big move would we rather have defined or undefined profit potential in that case I would rather have undefined profit potential because if it's going to be a big move I don't want to be limited by just getting the credit that I received or as I'm building a broader

text: big move would we rather have defined or undefined profit potential in that case I would rather have undefined profit potential because if it's going to be a big move I don't want to be limited by just getting the credit that I received or as I'm building a broader portfolio and I'm being aware of the impacts of Greeks on the portfolio and I realize well I have a bunch of long options I'm losing money every day in Theta maybe I want to try to sell some options in order to offset some of that Theta Decay so the idea is don't default to buying or selling use both of them in the context that it Mak sense so let's take a look at another example quickly if we take a look at something like Qualcomm which essentially has been trending sideways for the past three months straight even through earnings doesn't really look like it's making big moves to the upside or to the downside well I don't want to buy options because it's not moving enough so maybe this becomes an an instance where selling options can be a great add to the overall portfolio adds a diversification in terms of different profit mechanisms and it offsets some of the Theta it gives me positive Theta so if we take a look at some of the common misconceptions we already talked about one not being better than the other but the other thing we have to

text: a diversification in terms of different profit mechanisms and it offsets some of the Theta it gives me positive Theta so if we take a look at some of the common misconceptions we already talked about one not being better than the other but the other thing we have to highlight here is overweighting volatility there are a lot of traders that will automatically default to selling premium if implied volatility or implied volatility percentile is high and they will default to the inverse if it's low via buying and that's a mistake the reason why it's a mistake is Because unless you are actively Delta in gamma hedging to truly isolate volatility Delta is still the more important input to your formula what does that mean well let's take a look if we take a look at qualcom we might say implied volatility percentile is 54 let's just say that this was really low let's say implied volatility percentile was 10 if you're an option seller you would look at that and say oh well that's super low I don't want to sell volatility there it's too cheap and if volatility expands it'll hurt my position it will however it's temporary because as long as Qualcomm remains range bound if we sell a strangle for example even if your position temporarily hurts because volatility has gone up data is still going to Decay and as long as it remains range bound you're going to have a full profit at

text: it's temporary because as long as Qualcomm remains range bound if we sell a strangle for example even if your position temporarily hurts because volatility has gone up data is still going to Decay and as long as it remains range bound you're going to have a full profit at the end of it so volatility is a massively important consideration when you are looking to buy or sell options it's a a massive input is a decision Factor however it should not be the decision Factor it shouldn't be default to selling or buying based on volatility alone unless again you're deploying a specific volatility trade that's different of course volatility then becomes the primary input that is your actual profit mechanism so that is exactly how I think about buying versus selling premium the main decision it's going to come down to is what kind of risk profile do I want I'm going to manage it whether it's bought or sold so it doesn't matter quite that much and then the second is how do I feel about the profit potential given the corresponding tradeoffs if I have something that's an undefined profit I know I'm going to have a lower probability of profit I'm going to have to be better at picking Direction and it's going to have to move in my favor within the expected time frame and I have a video Down Below on buying options smarter that shows how to balance some of these
